numbered_ace_sentences: 1. Legacy students tend to have higher admission rates than non-legacy students.
2. This tendency holds across all income rankings.
3. Income seems to be a determining factor for admission rates.
4. Students in the top 10% of family income are more likely to be admitted than students in the bottom 10% of family income.
5. Students are more likely to be admitted if their family income is higher.
6. Many colleges claim that they are need-blind when they evaluate college applications.
7. If colleges are need-blind, then the admission-rate difference must be due to other factors.
8. Some other factors are influenced by higher income.
9. Students with more resources have easier access to information.
10. Students with more resources have easier access to tutors.
11. Students with more resources have easier access to outside assistance.
12. These resources are likely to improve academic performance.
13. These resources are likely to improve college applications.
14. Students with fewer resources are disadvantaged compared to students with more resources.
15. The graph shows that family background can affect a student's life.
16. A student has no control over the student's family background.
17. A student with higher family income typically becomes more successful than a student with lower family income.
18. A student with more access to resources typically becomes more successful than a student with less access to resources.
19. The community should address students with less access to resources for academic excellence.
20. If the community addresses this issue, then the community can reduce the disparity between legacy students and non-legacy students.
21. If the community addresses this issue, then the community can reduce the disparity between high-income students and low-income students.
22. The headline is: Leaving Others Behind: Legacy and High-Income Students Secure College Spots at Unfairly High Rates.
